content:
You need to check first using webmail whether the messages are arriving at the server and it's Thunderbird that doesn't see them, or it's the incoming mail server that's not receiving the messages in the first place, in which case the problem has nothing to do with Thunderbird…

What type of account is this (POP/IMAP)? Which is your email provider?

Read the following article in the meantime to see possible causes of the problem:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/cannot-receive-messages
creator: DavidGG

content:
In 2016 Midco acquired WOW! cable, internet and phone. I kept my wowway email account and also created a midco account. The wowway email worked fine until a week ago. It now can send messages but not receive them. It is a POP account. I chatted with a midco tech, who said "yes, midco acquired the wowway accounts, but not yours." Obviously untrue, but I think it means that the account has disappeared from midco's records. In server settings, I adjusted the Port number to agree with the functioning midco account -- no success. and I tried changing the connection security to "password, transmitted insecurely".

When I click between accounts, in the lower left corner both accounts say "loading messages" on both accounts. When I click the cloud in upper left, midco says "No messages", but wowway does not say anything.

Thank you DavidGG for responding.
creator: uuilliamfleissner

content:
Reinstalling Thunderbird won't make a difference. Using another mail client might, not because there is anything wrong with Thunderbird in this regard, but because you'd have to set up the account again and that could reveal some mistake you made when setting up the account in Thunderbird. Or it might still not work in Outlook for you even though it does for them, which would be informative as well…

I find funny these error messages where they tell you there is a problem with the sender but you should check the recipient, don't really understand that… But anyway, a possible cause of this problem could be that the message's "From" doesn't match the username used to authenticate with the SMTP server, for example. It would help if you post a screenshot of your outgoing server settings, in case there is something you're missing there.

And you may want to take a look at the following article in the meantime:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/cannot-send-messages
creator: DavidGG

content:
Click the Browse button for Local Directory in Account Settings and select the folder where the account stored mail before it was removed, e.g. if the Local Directory now points to ...pop.gmail-1.com, browse to pop.gmail.com.

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Recovering_deleted_mail_accounts

creator: davidsk

content:
You need to already have an email address with eg: Internet Service Provider or a free one with eg@ gmail, yahoo, gmx OR have an email address provided by an organisation you work for OR you own a domain and have set up an email address.

You should make sure you are able to connect to the server via a third party email client app such as Thunderbird - sometimes you need to logon to webmail account via a browser and enable Pop and/or Imap.

In Thunderbird you can then create a New mail account which uses either Pop or IMAP - depends upon what you want to use or what the server will offer. You should make sure you know what server settings you need to use because they are very specific and unique for each server.

In Thunderbird

  • Menu icon > New Account > Email
  • follow instructions.

Please note: sometimes you need to do a few additional setups or enable specific settings, but that depends upon what server you are using. For example: gmail uses 'Authentication Method: OAuth' and that requires cookies enabled, VPN disabled, anything using 'localhost' eg: Xampp to be temp swiched off whilst settings up Oauth token. If you need more info then you need to post more information about your requirements.

As aheads up when asking for any help it's always useful to know what OS you are using and what version of Thunderbird. If you get error message then post image of it or if issue with email or server settings then we need to know what server you are talking about and whether you use Pop or IMAP.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
creator: @next

content:
By default the developers thought it would be a really neat idea to cause confusion for people who never used Cards View, so they enabled it by default.

You want to use 'Table View'.

Newer version have something called 'Message List Header' toolbar and to the right of the 'Quick Filter' button is a new icon - click on it and then select 'Table View' from the drop down. I've added an image below as a guide.


To get image dispay in the Message Pane header area when you select to open and read an email.

  • Select email so it displays in Message Pane
  • click on 'More' and select 'Customise'
  • Select checkbox for 'show sender's profile picture'
  • Click on 'Done'

The image is the one you use in the Address Book for the contact.

I did find that I had to restart Thunderbird to force it to update whatever file it needed to update after I had added an image for a contact.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Do this. You are on the right track. If you want to do this in thunderbird, install the importexporttools addon and do these steps: - highlight each folder to save - rightclick and select importexport option to extract mbox - repeat for each folder - next, highllight Local Folders - rightclick and select importexport option to import mbox - repeat for each folder

you can also do this from windows file explorer when thunderbird is not running by copying the message folders from the account and pasting into Local Folders folder.
creator: davidsk

creator: FoxJT

content: That export is NOT what you want. And I wouldn't trust it anyway. Mozilla recommends not exporting more than 2 gb, and that export is always problem-prone. To save what you want, exit thunderbird and access the profile from Linux file manager. I am no Linux guru but I think profile is .thunderbird and what you want is in the Mail\<accountname> folder - inbox, sent, etc. Copy them and paste into the Mail\Local Folders folder while thunderbird is not running and then restart thunderbird and I think they will appear - ignore the msf files, as thunderbird will recreate them.
creator: davidsk
